info.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 08 at 9:08AM PST until January 08 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Portland
info.description: ...BLIZZARD CONDITIONS EXPECTED FOR THE CASCADE PASSES AND ABOVE TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY... .OVERVIEW...The heaviest snow so far this season is on its way to the Cascades after a strong cold front sweeps across the Pacific Northwest Monday night, ushering in much colder air and more seasonable snow levels for Tuesday. Strong and deep onshore flow will lead to periods of heavy snow, strong winds, and near zero visibility for the Cascades, especially for exposed areas above 3500 feet. This has prompted us to issue a rare Blizzard Warning for the Cascade passes and above, with Winter Storm Warnings extending as low as 1500 to 2000 feet in the Cascade foothills. By the time snow showers decrease Wednesday, elevations 3000 feet and above will likely be measuring their snow in feet, rather than inches. ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST THIS AFTERNOON ABOVE 1500 FEET... ...WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 4 AM TUESDAY TO 4 PM PST WEDNESDAY ABOVE 1500 FEET... * WHAT...Wet snow and possible freezing rain today. Heavy snow and gusty winds expected Tuesday through Wednesday. Snow accumulation of 1 to 4 inches today, with a light glaze of ice possible. Snow accumulations of 6 to 14 inches Tuesday through Wednesday, with heaviest accumulations above 2000 feet. Winds gusting up to 55 mph on exposed ridges. * WHERE...Upper Hood River Valley above 1500 feet. * WHEN... Winter Weather Advisory....from 4 AM to 4 PM Monday. Winter Storm Warning.......from 4 AM Tuesday to 4 PM Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Strong winds could cause tree damage. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...After a period where snow levels are well above the Cascade passes Monday night, snow levels will plummet to around 1500 to 2000 feet by midday Tuesday.
info.instruction: If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in your vehicle in case of an emergency. For the latest road conditions call 5 1 1, or visit for Oregon: https://www.tripcheck.com and for Washington: https://wsdot.com/travel/real-time/map
